official-title.#text:
To provide for the implementation of the negotiated property division regarding Former Fort Wingate
			 Depot Activity in McKinley County, New Mexico, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Return of Certain Lands At Fort Wingate to The Original Inhabitants Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Return of Certain Lands At Fort Wingate to The Original Inhabitants Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
Congress finds the following:

quote.#tail: ), ceased, and the installation was closed pursuant to

text.#text:
In January 1993, the active mission of the Fort Wingate Activity Depot located in McKinley County,
			 New Mexico (in this Act referred to as

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
title II of the Defense Authorization
			 Amendments and Base Closure and Realignment Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Defense Authorization Amendments and Base Closure and Realignment Act/t:II

text.#text:
The lands occupied by the Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity were originally the ancestral lands of
			 both the Zuni Tribe and Navajo Nation, as indicated by the ancestral
			 history and large number of archaeological and cultural sites identified
			 on the lands.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, with the support of the Zuni Tribe, the Navajo Nation, and other
			 concerned parties, determined that upon completion of environmental
			 remediation of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity, lands no longer needed
			 by the
would be transferred to the

and held in trust by the United States for the benefit of the
			 Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , with
and

present, for final discussions to
			 fairly divide Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity.

text.#text:
On July 8, 2013, the Zuni Tribe and Navajo Nation, acting through the respective tribal leadership,
			 who received authority from their tribal governments to enter into good
			 faith discussions, and through their respective legal representatives, met
			 in the Capitol office of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (in this Act referred to as the

was created in consultation with the Zuni Tribe and
			 the Navajo Nation.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Return of Certain Lands At Fort Wingate to The Original Inhabitants Act/s:3

quote.#text: Fort Wingate Depot Activity Negotiated Property Divisions July 2013

quote.#tail: ), and the land division outlined in

text.#text:
In the resulting discussions, the tribal leaders informally agreed to the property divisions
			 reflected in the map titled

This Act achieves the goal of fairly dividing Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity for the benefit of
			 the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation.

header.#text:

			 Zuni Tribe and Navajo Nation

for the Zuni Tribe as part of the Zuni Reservation, unless the
			 Zuni Tribe otherwise elects under subparagraphs (B) and (C) of subsection
			 (c)(3) to have the parcel conveyed to it in Restricted Fee Status.

text.#text:
Not later than 60 days after the date on which the New Mexico Environmental Department certifies
			 that remediation of a parcel of land of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity
			 has been completed consistent with

assumes administrative

			 under paragraph (1), the

shall notify the Zuni
			 Tribe and Navajo Nation of the transfer of administrative jurisdiction

text.#text: Not later than 30 days after the date on which the
for the Zuni Tribe, in the case of land depicted in blue on the Map; or
for the Navajo Nation, in the case of land depicted in green on the Map.

text.#text: Except as provided in subparagraph (B), the

convey the parcel or any portion of the parcel

text.#text:
In lieu of having a parcel of land held in trust under subparagraph (A), the Zuni Tribe, with
			 respect to land depicted in blue on the Map, and the Navajo Nation, with
			 respect to land depicted in green on the Map, may elect to have the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
of an
			 election under subparagraph (B) for conveyance of the parcel or any
			 portion of the parcel in restricted fee status.

text.#text:
Not later than 45 days after the date on which the Zuni Tribe or the Navajo Nation receives notice
			 under paragraph (2) of the transfer of administrative jurisdiction over a
			 parcel of land of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity, the Zuni Tribe or
			 the Navajo Nation shall notify the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall convey, in restricted fee
			 status, the parcel of land of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity covered
			 by the notice to the Zuni Tribe or the Navajo Nation, as the case may be.

text.#text:
As soon as practicable after receipt of a notice from the Zuni Tribe or the Navajo Nation under
			 subparagraph (C), but in no case later than 6 months after receipt of the
			 notice, the
shall be owned in fee by the Indian tribe to whom the land is conveyed;

shall be part of the Indian tribe’s Reservation and expressly made subject to the jurisdiction of
			 the Indian Tribe;
shall not be sold by the Indian tribe without the consent of Congress;

shall not be subject to taxation by any government other than the government of the Indian tribe;
			 and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
before an Indian tribe may use the land for any purpose,
			 directly or through agreement with another party.

text.#text: shall not be subject to any provision of law providing for the review or approval by the

text.#text: For purposes of this Act only, the term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—

text.#text: The

provide for the survey of lands of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity taken into trust for the Zuni
			 Tribe or the Navajo Nation or conveyed in restricted fee status for the
			 Zuni Tribe or the Navajo Nation under subsection (a), (b), or (c); and

establish legal boundaries based on the Map as parcels are taken into trust or conveyed in
			 restricted fee status.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall
			 consult with the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation to determine their
			 priorities regarding the order in which parcels should be surveyed, and,
			 to the greatest extent feasible, the Secretary shall follow these
			 priorities.

text.#text: Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

Part 151 of title 25, Code of Federal Regulations, shall not apply to taking lands of Former Fort
			 Wingate Depot Activity into trust under subsection (a), (b), or (c).

header.#text: Retention of necessary easements and access

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall be subject to reservation by the United States
			 of such easements as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Return of Certain Lands At Fort Wingate to The Original Inhabitants Act/s:3

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
determines are reasonably
			 required to permit access to lands of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity
			 for administrative, environmental cleanup, and environmental remediation
			 purposes. The

shall provide to the governments of
			 the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation written copies of all easements
			 reserved under this subsection.

text.#text:
The lands of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity held in trust or conveyed in restricted fee status
			 pursuant to

In the case of the lands of Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity depicted as Parcel 1 on the Map, the
			 lands shall be held in trust subject to a shared easement for cultural and
			 religious purposes only. Both the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation shall
			 have unhindered access to their respective cultural and religious sites
			 within Parcel 1. Within 1 year after the date of the enactment of this
			 Act, the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation shall exchange detailed
			 information to document the existence of cultural and religious sites
			 within Parcel 1 for the purpose of carrying out this paragraph. The
			 information shall also be provided to the

header.#text: Parcel 1 shared cultural and religious access

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may facilitate shared access to other lands held in trust or
			 restricted fee status pursuant to

, including, but not limited
			 to, religious and cultural sites.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Return of Certain Lands At Fort Wingate to The Original Inhabitants Act/s:3

text.#text: Subject to the written consent of both the Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation, the

quote.#tail:
on the Map, shall be held in common by the Zuni Tribe and Navajo Nation to provide for equal
			 access to Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity.

text.#text:
The access road for the Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity, which originates at the frontage road
			 for Interstate 40 and leads to the parcel of the Former Fort Wingate Depot
			 Activity depicted as

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall be subject to
			 easements reasonably required to permit access to the

text.#text:
Nothing in this Act shall be construed as alleviating, altering, or affecting the responsibility of
			 the United States for cleanup and remediation of Former Fort Wingate Depot
			 Activity according to the terms previously agreed to by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
activities on Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity or
			 the use by the

of hazardous substances, toxic
			 substances, heavy metals, explosives, pollutants, contaminants, waste or
			 petroleum products, or any combination thereof, regardless of when the
			 contamination is discovered or where it has spread.

text.#text: Neither the Zuni Tribe nor the Navajo Nation shall be liable for any damages resulting from

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
activities on or off the
			 Former Fort Wingate Depot Activity site, or the prior use of hazardous
			 substances, toxic substances, heavy metals, explosives, pollutants,
			 contaminants, waste or petroleum products, or any combination thereof,
			 regardless of when the contamination is discovered or where it has spread.

text.#text:
The Zuni Tribe and the Navajo Nation shall be held harmless from any claim, suit, demand, judgment,
			 cost, or fee arising from

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
of the existence or discovery of any contamination or
			 hazardous material on the parcel.
